title: Quotation of the Day: Smoldering Gaza Becomes a Graveyard for Children
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 19, 2023.
content: “The children’s bodies come to us broken and in pieces. It’s chilling.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordan Rau
title: What to Know About Assisted Living
description: The facilities can look like luxury apartments or modest group homes, and can vary in pricing structures. Here’s a guide.
content: Are you confused about what an assisted-living facility is, and how it differs from a nursing home? And what you can expect to pay? Here’s a guide to this type of housing for older people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Mocks George Santos and Welcomes a Sassy Panda
description: Jason Momoa hosted an episode that also poked fun at President Biden’s meeting with Xi Jinping and Thanksgiving travel.
content: Making his second appearance in the role of President Biden, Mikey Day was quickly overshadowed by a sassy panda played by Bowen Yang in a “Saturday Night Live” sketch that parodied a presidential news conference from earlier this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek
title: At Least 24 Killed in Strike on Gaza School Run by the U.N.
description: Nearly 7,000 people were sheltering at the school, according to the United Nations. Another school had been struck on Friday.
content: A strike this weekend on a school run by the United Nations that was being used for shelter by thousands of displaced people in northern Gaza killed at least 24 people, a U.N. official said Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ayana Mathis
title: Why Do Evil and Suffering Exist? Religion Has One Answer, Literature Another.
description: In the third installment of an essay series on literature and faith, Ayana Mathis explores how writers have grappled with one of theology’s oldest conundrums.
content: In the church of my childhood, we believed God’s angels battled demons in a war for our souls. This was not a metaphor. We were Pentecostals, though not strictly and not always. We weren’t picky about denomination; what mattered was belief in the redeeming blood of Christ, in the Bible literally interpreted and in God’s endless love. And evil. We believed in evil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch, Flávia Milhorance and Leonardo Coelho
title: After Eras Tour Triumphs, Taylor Swift Finds Trouble in Brazil
description: Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour broke records in North America, but has faced tragedy and mishaps during a three-day stretch of concerts in Rio de Janeiro.
content: Taylor Swift was welcomed to Brazil on Thursday by a projection that made the world-famous Christ the Redeemer statue in Rio de Janeiro appear as if it were clad in a T-shirt similar to the one she wore in her “You Belong to Me” music video and was decorated with the names of Brazilian states and symbols from her songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: The Tyranny of Hotness
description: Why beauty always commandeers the spotlight.
content: A beautiful person is so often a confrontation. Even in silence, symmetrical features announce their presence and elicit a reaction: desire, admiration, curiosity, resentment, belittlement, rage or envy. The response is rarely neutral.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aida Alami
title: As Morocco Tries to Rebuild After Quake, Tradition Is Top of Many Minds
description: Experts say the government should preserve cultural and architectural heritage, while also building disaster-resistant homes. In the meantime, residents are living in tents and in limbo.
content: Boujemaa Kouti still remembers the screams of his neighbors trapped under the rubble of their houses, calling for help that horrific night 63 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: A 30-Year Trap: The Problem With America’s Weird Mortgages
description: One big reason the U.S. housing market is broken: Owners don’t want to give up their cushy old loans.
content: Buying a home was hard before the pandemic. Somehow, it keeps getting harder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Schaefer
title: Derek Hough, America’s Ballroom Ambassador, Hits the Road
description: A judge on “Dancing with the Stars,” Hough has become one of the country’s most visible dancers. Now his “Symphony of Dance” is touring to 60 cities.
content: In one week this fall, Derek Hough visited five states as part of his 60-city concert tour “Symphony of Dance.” After a show in Cincinnati, and a post-show ice bath, he flew to Los Angeles for 48 hours to appear on Jennifer Hudson’s talk show, rehearse an upcoming Disney holiday special and film an episode of “Dancing With the Stars,” the hit television ballroom and Latin dance competition that helped start his career 16 years ago. Then he flew to Michigan for the next show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Vivek Shankar, Isabel Kershner and Michael Levenson
title: Infants Moved From ‘Death Zone’ Hospital That Israel Says Was Hamas Hideout
description: U.N. officials said 31 premature babies in precarious health were evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital to a hospital further south in Gaza.
content: Four days after it was seized by Israeli troops, the Gaza Strip’s largest hospital has become a “death zone,” the World Health Organization said, as 31 premature babies in extremely precarious health there were evacuated on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: London Police Question Russell Brand About Past Allegations
description: The British news media reported on Sunday that he was questioned in connection with three sex offenses.
content: The British police questioned Russell Brand, the comedian, actor and YouTuber, in relation to three allegations that he had committed sexual offenses, according to British news reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Focuses on Iowa as He Looks to Close Out the Republican Race
description: The former president has made Iowa his priority, hoping to thin the field and turn his attention to a campaign against President Biden.
content: With just under two months until the Iowa caucuses, former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday returned to the state and made explicit a campaign strategy that he had only hinted at for months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Jessica Jaglois
title: Man Suspected of Killing 4 in Memphis Is Found Dead After Hourslong Manhunt
description: The shootings across three locations killed three women and one 13-year-old girl, and critically injured one 15-year-old, the police said.
content: A man suspected of fatally shooting three women and a 13-year-old girl in Memphis was found dead early Sunday with what appeared to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the police said, ending an hourslong manhunt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Argentina Elects Javier Milei in Victory for Far Right
description: Argentina’s next president is a libertarian economist whose brash style and embrace of conspiracy theories has parallels with those of Donald J. Trump.
content: Argentines on Sunday chose Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian who has drawn comparisons to Donald J. Trump, as their next president, a lurch to the right for a nation struggling under an economic crisis and a sign of the enduring strength of the global far right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: For Years, Two Men Shuttled Messages Between Israel and Hamas. No Longer.
description: Since 2006, Gershon Baskin, an Israeli peace activist, and Ghazi Hamad, a Hamas official, maintained a secret back channel between Gaza and Israel. Then Oct. 7 happened.
content: For 17 years, on and off, two men maintained a secret line of communication between Israel and Hamas, the armed Palestinian group that opposes Israel’s existence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Rosalynn Carter, First Lady and a Political Partner, Dies at 96
description: She helped propel Jimmy Carter from rural Georgia to the White House and became the most politically active first lady since Eleanor Roosevelt
content: Rosalynn Carter, a true life partner to Jimmy Carter who helped propel him from rural Georgia to the White House in a single decade and became the most politically active first lady since Eleanor Roosevelt, died on Sunday in Plains, Ga. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 19, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 19, 2023.
content: An article on Page 6 this weekend about a new biopic on the civil rights leader Bayard Rustin misstates the middle initial of an author. He is Michael G. Long, not Michael C. Long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: A Cancer Patient’s Last Wish: To Pay Off the Medical Debt of Others
description: Casey McIntyre organized a campaign that has raised nearly $220,000 since she died a week ago. The funds are expected to pay off more than $20 million in debt, an official said.
content: A 38-year-old woman with ovarian cancer who started a campaign to help people pay off their medical debt has raised more than $200,000 in the week since she died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 27, 2023
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Note: Comments are open for student responses. Live moderated discussion of this photograph will take place on Monday, Nov. 27.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: It Seemed to Have It All: 9 Dancers, 5 Guitars, 5 Amps
description: But “takemehome,” a look at isolation by Dimitri Chamblas in collaboration with the musician Kim Gordon, fades into its own shadows at NYU Skirball.
content: The dance started — or seemed to start — with people walking onto the stage before finding a spot and lying down. The bright, blisteringly white lights made the view murky, yet through the haze random bodies were stretched out on backs and sides, utterly limp. Above them was a suspended zeppelin: Imagine a giant balloon of a baked potato floating over 34th Street in the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: What Endures After a Climate Activist’s Suicide: Grief, Anger and Hope
description: Five years ago, David Buckel violently ended his life in a public park in Brooklyn. People who knew him were shocked and angry. Yet they refused to give up.
content: They were walking up Ninth Street in Park Slope as they often did after work, each man a movie unto himself: one a crusading L.G.B.T.Q. rights attorney who quit the law to shovel dirt, the other a young man from the projects who became his most brilliant protégé.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Monday Briefing: Babies Evacuated From Al-Shifa
description: Plus: A woman’s unconventional escape in India.
content: Nearly four days after the Israeli military stormed the biggest hospital in the Gaza Strip, the World Health Organization described the complex as a “death zone” where several patients had died because medical services had been shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guido Alfani
title: What Happens When the Super Rich Are This Selfish? (It Isn’t Pretty.)
description: In a break from the past, the Western world’s wealthiest people no longer try to support the societies they live in.
content: Throughout much of the Western world’s history, the wealthiest have been viewed in their communities as a potentially unfavorable presence, and they have attempted to allay this sentiment by using their riches to support their societies in times of crises like plagues, famines or wars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: F.B.I. Faulted Agents for Shooting at a Fleeing Suspect and Killing a Family Dog
description: Agents rarely get in trouble for intentionally firing their guns at people or animals. The two “bad shoot” incidents were not previously known.
content: The F.B.I. faulted agents in 2019 for misusing their guns in two separate shootings, each an exceedingly rare internal finding of violations of its lethal force policy, according to documents obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: An Old Hate Cracks Open on the New Right
description: Antisemitism breaks loose on the populist right wing.
content: A dam burst last week on the right, and a wave of grotesque antisemitism poured out all over the internet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: In Hitler’s Birthplace, Soul-Searching Over a Poisonous Past
description: The Austrian government is turning the house where Hitler was born into a police station. But many think it should be used instead to teach essential lessons about history.
content: The Austrian town of Braunau am Inn, sitting just at the border with Germany, has a 15th-century church tower, cobblestone streets and cluttered rows of charming, colorful houses, some in green, pink and blue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eli Saslow and Erin Schaff
title: A Jan. 6 Defendant Pleads His Case to the Son Who Turned Him In
description: The Capitol attacks ruptured their mutual trust. In the weeks before Brian Mock’s sentencing, could he mend the divide with his son A.J.?
content: The trial was over and the verdict was in, but Brian Mock, 44, kept going back through the evidence, trying to make his case to the one person whose opinion he valued most. He sat at his kitchen table in rural Wisconsin next to his son, 21-year-old A.J. Mock, and opened a video on his laptop. He leaned into the screen and traced his finger over the image of the U.S. Capitol building, looked through clouds of tear gas and smoke and then pointed toward the center of a riotous crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Guerrero
title: Future Designs the First Lanvin Lab Collection
description: The collaboration between the fashion house and the entertainer is the latest example of the growing union between the two industries.
content: On Monday, the French fashion house Lanvin will release its inaugural Lanvin Lab collection with Future, the rapper and producer. Earlier this year, Future was brought on, temporarily, to help design the collection for Lanvin Lab, the brand’s new design arm that will focus on rotating collaborations. More pieces from the unisex ready-to-wear collection, all designed by Future, will debut next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis’s Two-Pronged Approach in Iowa: Hit Trump on Abortion, and Get Personal
description: The Florida governor is courting white evangelicals by using Donald J. Trump’s criticisms of hard-line abortion restrictions against him.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida paused, looked down and then told a banquet hall filled with conservative Iowa Christians something that he had never before said in public: His wife, Casey DeSantis, experienced a miscarriage several years ago during her first pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Premature Babies Are Evacuated From Embattled Hospital in Gaza
description: The 31 babies will be taken to Egypt for treatment, officials say. Israel’s push to seize Al-Shifa Hospital and a lack of power led doctors to warn that the infants were at particular risk.
content: Thirty-one premature babies were evacuated from the embattled Al-Shifa Hospital in northern Gaza on Sunday and taken to another hospital in the enclave’s south, the Palestine Red Crescent Society and the World Health Organization said on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: The N.Y.P.D. Is Upgrading Its Radios. The Public Won’t Be Able to Tune In.
description: The New York Police Department is spending $500 million on a new radio system it calls more reliable and secure. But the public will no longer be able to monitor what officers are doing minute to minute.
content: John Roca cruised through Midtown Manhattan on a recent night just as the streetlights flicked on, his camera in the back seat of his sedan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Cashier’s Expression Saved Me From Having to Ask the Obvious’
description: A second life for a lunch receipt, a late summer storm and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: Mick Herron Has Made a Blockbuster Career Writing About Foul-Ups and Has-Beens
description: The author of the “Slow Horses” series says he relates more with failures. With millions of books sold and the third season of the series airing next month, he may have to wrap his head around success.
content: In 2013, Mick Herron’s rickety literary career looked to be falling apart. None of his novels had sold more than a few hundred copies, and “Slow Horses,” the first book in his acidly funny series about a band of misfits in the British intelligence services, had performed so badly that its sequel, “Dead Lions, could not find a British publisher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Michael Gold
title: Texas Governor Endorses Trump, Lauding His Border Policies
description: Gov. Greg Abbott threw his support behind the former president in the Republican presidential primary at an event near the southern border.
content: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas endorsed former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday in an appearance near the southern border, echoing Mr. Trump’s talk about an existential crisis of illegal immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: A Mother’s Search for Her Son Leads to a Pauper’s Grave and More Questions
description: Bettersten Wade spent months calling the police for help finding her son, without being told that an off-duty officer driving an S.U.V. had fatally struck him on the same day she last saw him.
content: For months, Bettersten Wade called the police in Jackson, Miss., desperate for any update or sign that detectives were making progress in tracking down Dexter, her 37-year-old son who left their home one day in March and vanished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac, Cade Metz, Tripp Mickle and Erin Griffith
title: Talks to Bring Sam Altman Back to OpenAI Stretch Through Weekend
description: Disagreements over the board’s makeup appear to have muddled negotiations. Mr. Altman was forced out as chief executive by the company’s board on Friday.
content: Talks at OpenAI to bring back Sam Altman, the artificial intelligence start-up’s recently ousted chief executive, continued into Sunday evening but there were disagreements over the makeup of the company’s board of directors, according to two people familiar with the discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: You’ve Planned Your Play. Now Play Your Plan.
description: Cheesy Hasselback potato gratin for Sunday (and Thursday); tofu and green beans with chile crisp for Monday.
content: Good morning. For those of us who take Thanksgiving seriously, who plan and plan and cook and cook, this last Sunday before the feast marks the real start of the holiday. I’m cleaning out my fridge and freezer to make room for an epic trip to the supermarket, cataloging serving platters and cooking vessels, making sure I have enough mismatched knives and forks to serve (checks notes) 32 people. (Yikes! I’m short two dozen chairs!)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: What to Know as Argentina Votes in a Pivotal Election
description: On Sunday, voters will choose whether to elect a far-right libertarian, Javier Milei, or the center-left economy minister, Sergio Massa.
content: For months, Argentina has been consumed by a single question.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Gertner, Adrienne Hurst, Diane Wong, John Woo, Sophia Lanman and Zachary Mouton
title: The Sunday Read: ‘What Does the U.S. Space Force Actually Do?’
description: Inside the highly secretive military branch responsible for protecting American interests in a vulnerable new domain.
content: The Space Force, the sixth and newest branch of the U.S. military, was authorized by Congress and signed into law by President Donald Trump in December 2019. The initiative had been shaped within the armed forces and Congress over the previous 25 years, based on the premise that as satellite and space technologies evolved, America’s military organizations had to change as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordan Rau
title: Extra Fees Drive Assisted-Living Profits
description: The add-ons pile up: $93 for medications, $50 for cable TV. Prices soar as the industry leaves no service unbilled. The housing option is out of reach for many families.
content: Assisted-living centers have become an appealing retirement option for hundreds of thousands of boomers who can no longer live independently, promising a cheerful alternative to the institutional feel of a nursing home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and Aaron Krolik
title: The Invisible War in Ukraine Being Fought Over Radio Waves
description: Using electromagnetic waves to flummox and follow smarter weapons has become a critical part of the cat-and-mouse game between Ukraine and Russia. The United States, China and others have taken note.
content: The drones began crashing on Ukraine’s front lines, with little explanation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: From Vegetation to Prevarication, Hedge’s Meaning Has Grown
description: As a verb, “hedge” first meant to create a border with shrubbery. But it’s not just land that can be hedged: so too can bets, investments and words.
content: In June, Debra Kamin, who covers real estate, wrote about the hedges that hid the homes of Hollywood’s rich and famous: “From the street, a passer-by would have no idea that an alternate universe exists just beyond their leafy green walls.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: The Shape of a Rainbow
description: Sam Ezersky leaves us in a state of disarray.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Scott Pilgrim Takes Off,’ Almost
description: Not quite a reboot or a sequel, this anime series brings back the cast of the beloved “Scott Pilgrim” movie but lands without the same charm.
content: Did you know that at some point in the ’90s there were two separate, very different Sonic the Hedgehog TV series running simultaneously? “And the same guy played Sonic in both shows,” Scott Pilgrim, the doofy 23-year-old layabout of “Scott Pilgrim Takes Off,” shares, unprompted, to his love interest, Ramona Flowers. “Isn’t that wild? The same guy playing two different versions of the same guy??”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin and Emmanuel Morgan
title: Off the Court and Field, Top Athletes Become Players in the Art Market
description: Sports figures are increasingly becoming serious collectors, helping drive interest in contemporary art and particularly in artists of color.
content: Carmelo Anthony, the 10-time N.B.A. All-Star who announced his retirement in May, said that when he was starting out as a professional basketball player he did not understand art, but grew to appreciate it and began collecting as he matured. Now paintings by major Black artists including Nelson Makamo, Swoon, Rashid Johnson and Kehinde Wiley line the walls of his Westchester home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: What to Know About OpenAI’s Chaotic Weekend
description: Details about Sam Altman’s surprise departure as chief executive are still emerging, and the board has been tight-lipped so far.
content: OpenAI is one of the world’s highest-profile artificial intelligence companies. So the abrupt ouster of Sam Altman as its chief executive on Friday caused an immediate stir in the world of A.I. and among the investors who back it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: New Tool for Building and Fixing Roads and Bridges: Artificial Intelligence
description: In Pennsylvania and elsewhere, A.I. is being applied to the nation’s aging infrastructure. Is that wise?
content: In Pennsylvania, where 13 percent of the bridges have been classified as structurally deficient, engineers are using artificial intelligence to create lighter concrete blocks for new construction. Another project is using A.I. to develop a highway wall that can absorb noise from cars — and some of the greenhouse gas emissions that traffic releases as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Bobby Ussery, Hall of Fame Jockey, Is Dead at 88
description: He rode a 30-to-1 long shot, Proud Clarion, to victory in the 1967 Kentucky Derby. Over his career, he had 3,611 first-place finishes.
content: Bobby Ussery, the Hall of Fame jockey who won the 1960 Preakness Stakes and the 1967 Kentucky Derby and amassed 3,611 victories between 1951 and 1974, died on Thursday in Hollywood, Fla. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Swedish Soccer Prioritized Fans Over Finances. Now, Business Is Booming.
description: While most of Europe’s leagues engage in a Sisyphean quest to source as much money as possible, Sweden has chosen a different model. But its rewards come with risk.
content: The warning sounded over and over, first in Swedish and then in English. A fire had been detected. Please evacuate the stadium. The players left the field. Outside, fire crews were arriving. But in the stands, as a thick cloud of smoke wreathed and coiled in the floodlights, nobody moved. The fans were going to make the game happen by sheer force of will.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When Students’ Cellphones ‘Colonize Their Minds’
description: Readers discuss a column by Pamela Paul and a news story about a Florida school district’s ban. Also: The “catastrophists”; an example of compassion.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: ‘Murder’s Easy. We Did Something Much Worse.’
description: Our crime columnist recommends four newly published books.
content: There’s a mordant theme to this month’s column; in three of the four books, dark humor undercuts despair and sardonic wit compensates for failure. Nowhere are these traits more on display than in DEATH OF THE RED RIDER (Pushkin Vertigo, 396 pp., paperback, $16.95), the second appearance of Yulia Yakovleva’s Stalin-era detective, Vasily Zaitsev, who goes about the ordinary business of solving murders while communities around him in 1930s Russia are purged and exiled en masse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martin Riker
title: A Trip to the French Countryside, and Through Time
description: Mathias Énard’s new novel, “The Annual Banquet of the Gravediggers’ Guild,” considers the jumble of life in a variety of stories and styles.
content: To fully appreciate what Mathias Énard is up to in his new novel, “The Annual Banquet of the Gravediggers’ Guild,” it helps to know about the 16th-century French literary genius François Rabelais and his bawdy five-volume masterpiece, “Gargantua and Pantagruel.” A tale of giants who roam the French countryside having drunken adventures and upsetting social norms, Rabelais’s work has been a wellspring of laughter through much of Western literary history, inspiring writers for centuries, though these days he is probably more referred to than read.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: I-10 Freeway in Los Angeles to Fully Reopen Monday After Fire Repairs
description: Officials had feared that Interstate 10, a crucial artery for drivers, might have been closed for months after a fire on Nov. 11 severely damaged a section of it.
content: Interstate 10 in Los Angeles will fully reopen on Monday, more than a week after a fire severely damaged a section of the freeway, officials announced on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Eric Lipton
title: The White House May Condemn Musk, but the Government Is Addicted to Him
description: Rarely has the U.S. government so depended on the technology provided by a single technologist with views that it has so publicly declared repugnant.
content: The White House denounced Elon Musk on Friday for “abhorrent promotion of antisemitic and racist hate,” for his endorsement of what an administration spokesman called a “hideous lie” about Jews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: For an Aging President, a Birthday With a Bite
description: President Biden has no plans for a lavish public celebration when he turns 81 on Monday, even as Democrats search for a strategy to assuage voters’ concerns about his age by next year’s election.
content: For many of a certain age, there comes a point when marking yet another birthday, taking note of yet another passage of the calendar, is not greeted with the same enthusiasm it once was. And that’s for people who are not even running for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Wildman
title: The Empty Seat at Our Thanksgiving Table
description: After my daughter’s death, I have been approaching this holiday with trepidation.
content: Grieving parents like me are told to gird themselves for anniversaries and holidays, for birthdays and religious events. We’re advised to plan for days associated with joy. We consider exit strategies. We talk about how the markers of civil religion and religious observance are harder for us, now that we no longer exist exactly inside society, but run alongside it, observing. Each holiday centered on family is now barbed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Karel Schwarzenberg, Renegade Czech Prince and Politician, Dies at 85
description: Popular with the Czech public for quietly subverting the aristocracy, he served twice as foreign minister and ran for president in 2013.
content: Karel Schwarzenberg, a Czech prince who twice served as his country’s foreign minister, played a key role in the Velvet Revolution and quietly subverted aristocratic expectations, died shortly after midnight on Nov. 12 in a Vienna hospital. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Mack
title: The Sneaky Sticker-Shock of Subscription Culture
description: Silicon Valley has immersed us in an expensive, pervasive and perennially annoying type of automated capitalism.
content: In recent years, much of my life as a consumer has shifted to what I like to call background spending. As I’ve subscribed to more apps and streaming platforms, significant sums of my money tend to drift away each month without my ever thinking about it. It’s as if it were a tax being taken out of my paycheck, but one that is spent on something silly or indulgent like a subscription box of international snacks, instead of — I don’t know — basic public infrastructure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum and Callie Holtermann
title: It’s Thanksgiving. Will Ozempic Make It Better or Worse?
description: The weight-loss drugs that have swept into the cultural conversation crash into a holiday that’s all about food.
content: Last month, Gabie Caballero got a call from her brother inviting her to his home in Houston for a Thanksgiving feast. “As soon as he mentioned food and Thanksgiving, I felt overwhelmed,” Ms. Caballero, 46, said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aamina Inayat Khan
title: How Targeted Weight Loss Ads Can Haunt Future Brides
description: When women post about their engagements and upcoming weddings on social media, an unexpected, potentially damaging specter arrives: targeted weight loss ads.
content: After Lauren Aitchison became engaged in March 2022, she began seeing targeted ads for wedding content everywhere, with marketing phrases like “shredding for the wedding” and “bridal boot camp.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz, Mike Isaac and Erin Griffith
title: Sam Altman Is Said to Be Discussing Return to OpenAI With Company’s Board
description: Mr. Altman was forced out of the artificial intelligence start-up on Friday, leading to an outcry from his supporters and the company’s investors.
content: Sam Altman and Greg Brockman, two top executives at OpenAI who left the company after a dramatic board meeting on Friday, are talking again with board members about returning to the artificial intelligence start-up, two people with knowledge of the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

content: See all results and maps from the Louisiana general election.

author: By Nailah Morgan
title: Premature Babies Are Treated After Evacuation From Al-Shifa Hospital
description: Thirty-one premature babies were evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital in northern Gaza on Sunday and moved to a hospital in the south, according to the Palestine Red Crescent Society and the World Health Organization.
content: Thirty-one premature babies were evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital in northern Gaza on Sunday and moved to a hospital in the south, according to the Palestine Red Crescent Society and the World Health Organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona El-Naggar, Emily Rhyne and Noah Throop
title: Surviving War in Gaza, One Text Message at a Time
description: Every morning, Ahmed Mansour, a Palestinian filmmaker in the U.S., texts his family in Gaza to check if they are still alive. Israel’s siege on the territory has caused widespread communication blackouts, making it difficult for him to reach his parents and siblings.
content: Every morning, Ahmed Mansour, a Palestinian filmmaker in the U.S., texts his family in Gaza to check if they are still alive. Israel’s siege on the territory has caused widespread communication blackouts, making it difficult for him to reach his parents and siblings.
source.name: The New York Times
